results.title: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.
results.title_for_label: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 84]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

This film shows the ‘J. Gadsden Pty. Ltd.’ factory in North Coburg (now a heritage listed location) from early construction through to completion and operational. We see the production line during the manufacture of Coralite British Kerosene packaging and other unidentified products.

results.title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
results.creator_credit: Pyramid Films, David Adams, Nick Bosustow and Sam Weiss
results.brief_description: Visualizes the spectral spirits and twilight superstitions that haunted the drowsy Dutch settlement of Sleepy Hollow. Concerns the rivalry between Ichabod Crane and Brom Bones for the hand of Katrina Van Tassel, and how the Headless Horseman of Sleepy Hollow removes Ichabod from the scene. Screenplay by Joseph Cavella, based on the story by Washington Irving. Narrated by John Carradine.

results.title: Wool: fashion's choice for '62
results.creator_credit: Australian Wool Corporation and Frank Land
results.brief_description: Models strut the latest wool fashions, using locations around Melbourne as their backdrop. Some of these localities include the banks of the Yarra, Captain Cook’s Cottage, St Kilda Pier, King’s Domain, the Botanical and Exhibition Gardens, and the Myer Music Bowl. Commentated by Roger Climpson, Fashion adviser: Sybil Jackson and photographed by George Heath.

results.title: Wool Fashion Awards 1967
results.brief_description: Models are posed against a variety of Melbourne’s buildings such as Melbourne University, Fitzroy Gardens, National Gallery of Victoria…both interior and exterior backgrounds are used. We see the award winning garments: slack suits, lounging pyjamas, coats and dresses for both day and evening wear.

results.title: [Wool Fashion Awards 1965]
results.brief_description: Photographed against a background of Montsalvat at Eltham and Melbourne University, models pose in award winning day and evening wear: dresses, suits, skirts and informal wear.

results.creator_credit: Pyramid Films, Nick Bosustow, David Adams and Sam Weiss

results.title: Patterns
results.brief_description: Patterns is a documentary which explores issues to do with politics, work, art and women’s history. A number of threads are woven between the sweatshop and the art gallery, the glory box and the political banner, bourgeois femininity and the question: should a feminist knit? An incisive and kaleidoscopic exploration of needlework and its place in women’s lives.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film is a series of shorter films from different periods edited together. They include trips to Lake Eildon and the Eildon Weir Spillway and Dromana Beach. Streets of Ballarat and Alexandra are also briefly seen.

We see a doubles tennis tournament at Kooyong Stadium and a scene of the 1936 Australian golf exhibition tour with Gene Sarazen (USA), Jim Ferrier (Australia) and Helen Hicks (USA), the first professional female golfer in the world.

Included are members of the Parsons family, also playing tennis and golf, and towards the end of the film there is a raquet technique demonstration from Robin (George Robinson) Parsons himself.

In addition to showing fashions of the time there are brief scenes showing vehicles of the era, including a steam locomotive, ships, a row boat and horses. The two main vehicles seen are the family cars: a 1935 Chevrolet and 1933 Rover.

The film also includes a few scenes of dogs playing and doing tricks including the family terrier called Peter.

results.title: Wool: an exhibition of the Art Gallery of South Australia, Adelaide Festival of Arts, 1972
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Art Gallery of South Australia and Brian Kavanagh
results.brief_description: The versatility of wool is applied to artistic tapestries and home decor furnishings. Used by highly creative craftspeople, wool is knotted, twisted or woven, bunched and crunched, looped or drooped - to assemble many exciting textured designs. The film is centred on the creative applications of this exciting raw material. After a short voice-over introduction, the sound track is a series of inspired tone poems composed by the noted jazz musician Don Burrows and performed by his Quintet. The film includes exhibits by Judith Barnes, Robert Bell, Fay Bottrell, Arthur Boyd, John Coburn, Deanna Conti, John Olsen and others.
